The domain of a function is the set of all possible input values for which the function is defined. Every input value in the domain has a corresponding output in the codomain via the function.

An algebraic closure $\\[\overline{\mathbb{F}}_p\]$ of a finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$ is a field that contains $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$ and all its algebraic extensions. It is used to view the fields $\\[\mathbb{F}_{p^n}\]$ as subfields.
Does the concept of a/an Domain need to be defined for a definition of a/an Algebraic Closure of Finite Field to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The concept of a Domain, as defined, pertains to the set of all possible input values for which a function is defined. This concept is specific to functions and their operations. On the other hand, the concept of an Algebraic Closure of a Finite Field involves fields and their algebraic extensions, focusing on properties and elements of fields rather than functions and their domains. The definition of an Algebraic Closure of a Finite Field does not inherently involve or require the concept of a function's domain. Therefore, understanding or defining an Algebraic Closure of a Finite Field does not necessitate the concept of a Domain as defined in the context of functions.
